posts.name: Rishab
posts.cooked: What is your opinion on having an multi-intake system ? For example multiple intakes on the left, right, front, and back of the robot.

posts.name: Noudvanbrunscho
posts.cooked: If you have tankdrive i wouldn’t bother going for intaking from the left/right. If you have swervedrive you can just rotate and i wouldn’t bother going for the left/right intake either. We talked about back and front intake, you’ll see it more often than last year with the balls going everywhere. We for now decided not to go for it but i think it could be a good choice. I think we are going for one intake on the back of the robot since it would make autonomous easier.

posts.name: Jason Tran
posts.cooked: I think the fact that you can only store two cargo at a time makes it so having multiple intakes might be unnecessary (although with cargo scarcity and bouncing being a problem, being able to intake cargo quickly will improve cycle times).

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: Consider that you lose at least 12" of intake area going between the bumpers, and generally speaking maximizing intake area is typically a good thing. That being said, a set of intake rollers that extend outside of the frame is a valid way to gain some extra intake area.

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked:
Dr.RishTheFish:

What is your opinion on having an multi-intake system ?

Do you think the additional design complexity required from having two intakes, and the associated drive practice time you’ll lose during the build season, will be made up by the effectiveness of having two intakes?

I’ll strongly argue that a vast majority of teams would be better suited with a single intake, simpler robot, and more driver practice.
